segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Thank you very much, and thanks for having me.
It's great to be here.
I really have fond memories of being in Poland, excuse me, last year, so it was an excellent
conference and so I'm excited to present again.
This presentation, The Art of the Breach.
This presentation is a physical security presentation, however, I've added a few twists.
One is I really like physical security, and all the presentations I've watched always
focus on a specific area, and what I've always wanted to see was, okay, that's great, but
how do I go further, or how do I go all the way into a building from the sidewalk all
the way into, say, the executive filing cabinet, right?
So the complete journey.
So that's what I want to take you on today, but then also, due to what I do and the people
I spend time with, I have special knowledge around what we call forced entry.
So what I want to do is add that on as well as a third option.
As we proceed through that building, we're going to look at passive entry, social engineering,
covert entry, which is lock picking and that sort of thing, but then also forced entry,
which is really just kind of brute force.
I'm getting in any means possible.
So that's the journey I want to take you on today.
A little bit about myself before we get started.
So I am the founder and president of the nonprofit called Traced Labs.
We do crowdsourcing for open source intelligence for missing persons.
We do monthly CTFs.
We have one coming up next week if you're interested.
If you go to our website, you'll find more information about that.
As a profession, of course, I work in IT and security is a big component of that in
the aerospace industry.
I've been doing that for more years than I can remember.
I've competed at DEF CON twice in the SECTF, came in third twice there.
Great experience for anybody who's planning to do that.
Let me know and I can give you some tips on that.
I also volunteer in search and rescue and specialize as a tracker and that actually
helps me quite a bit with my OSINT.
And if you want to reach out to me, my Twitter and email address are there.
In particular, if you have suggestions for this talk, that would be great.
Any feedback is greatly appreciated.
Okay.
So the standard disclaimer, you know, really this material doesn't represent any employers,
past, present, or future.
I have a lot of bad ideas.
And so I wouldn't want that to transfer on to anybody else.
So risk of incarceration.
Of course, this material is going to take you through the journey from sidewalk to filing
cabinet and we're going to go through that and we're going to show you from an attacker's
point of view.
And of course, that could be used poorly in the wrong hands.
So really what I need to do is make sure that you all understand that really this is for
educational purposes, for a defender to see how an attacker would think, how an attacker
would proceed with your physical security, and how as a defender you can defend against
that.
All right.
So this overlay is basically a graphical representation of what we're going to do today.
So we're going to start off with some homework and go through the research.
And then we're going to arrive on site, that icon three in the bottom corner.
And then we're going to navigate our way through the building, deploying different
security breach techniques.
So the first thing we want to do is, of course, research our target.
This is where our OSINT comes in.
We want to do, of course, our passive reconnaissance, what I also call zero-touch reconnaissance.
We don't want them to know we're looking, of course.
And we want to start off at a high level and drill down into details.
Just deploying some best practices for OSINT, and we teach a lot of this at Trace Labs.
You want to probably use a dedicated VM if you can.
You know, use sock puppets if you can.
If you're not accustomed to using sock puppets, or if you don't have those set up, you can
use your account, but you'd have to be extremely careful.
During the SECTF, I used my own account on LinkedIn, and I'm looking at everybody's profile,
and the next day I noticed they're all looking back at me.
So total newbie mistake.
You don't want to do that.
So learn from my mistakes.
VPN, of course, is great too, and not just to protect your security, but it's also handy
to be able to appear somewhere else for OSINT and for this sort of thing.
So there are several reasons why you may want to look at a VPN for this type of work.
And then, of course, finally, organizing your OSINT.
So this is a big deal, and I think a lot of people jump into an OSINT operation without
properly kind of preparing for it that way.
Where am I going to put all my stuff, right?
How am I going to organize it by category?
What's important?
All those details.
So stop and put some thought into that before you jump right into it.
All right, and the other thing we want to do is really understand their business, right?
Do they make tires?
Are they a security company?
Because that would make a big difference, right?
If their focus is security, they're going to actually probably have a higher level of
security, we hope.
How big is it?
How many employees?
Is it just an executive office or just a field office?
What does that look like?
Look at the employees online.
Are there a lot of social butterflies?
That's the 80-20 rule.
I'm going to focus on those social butterflies because that's where I'm going to get all
my good OSINT, right?
I find that there's usually a couple people in any office that are just giving you everything.
So those are the ones you want to check out.
Vendors, this is another great one.
So this will help us develop our pretexts when we want to get into the building because
maybe I'm going to show up as their parking vendor or their cafeteria vendor or their
shredding vendor, anything like that.
But if I know who that company is, I can better prepare for that.
And now we want to take a look at their infrastructure.
So all the services that they consume, I'm interested in, but then also what are the
things that are on site?
One of the things you can often find is the floor plans.
So if they are renting or leasing the building, you can often find that online with the property
management company, first responder key boxes.
So I'm going to get into that.
That's going to be really interesting.
So cafeteria or gym, which one do they have?
If any, HVAC on the roof.
That's one of my go-to pretexts because I know a lot about that.
So it's easy for me to talk about it.
Whatever you know a lot about is much easier to use as your pretext.
So that's what I'd highly recommend in that case.
Ingress-egress points.
So if I do get in, okay, how do I get out?
So I really want to make sure that I understand my path for exit.
If I'm all the way in and all of a sudden I have to get out in a hurry, that's something
I really need to think about.
And you'll find that real criminals are very concerned about that too.
The last thing that they want is to be stuck with their hand in the cookie jar and get
caught with evidence.
We've had incidents where the person is confronted and they're trying to hide the stolen property
as they evade.
So watch out for that.
Magnetic locks.
So during a power outage, is it secure open or secure fail?
What does that look like?
Perimeter layers.
This is very important too.
So as a defense, layering is highly recommended.
So man traps, fences, all those things that deter attackers and make them think, yeah,
I'm going to go somewhere else.
So that's what we want to look for as an attacker.
Understand the defenses.
So do you have guards?
Do you have CCTV?
All these things are going to deter me.
They're all going to add up to that big picture.
What type of door locks do you have, right?
Did you just buy the cheapo locks or do you have good quality locks that are going to
cause me a problem?
Patterns of life.
So is the office open 24 by 7 and maybe they have a reduced security at certain points?
Is it a very fluid environment where we see people coming and going all the time?
Or is it much more formalized?
So everybody's maybe wearing a suit with official ID, what does that look like?
Some great sources for that, of course, are YouTube office tours I find are golden.
If you can find one of those, if your company has one of those out there, I would watch
it in slow motion and even frame by frame if you want.
Because I can tell you, as an attacker, you can quite often find just golden nuggets out
of that.
What type of ID cards they use, where security cameras are, all the good stuff.
And then of course, employee social media is usually, you're going to find one or two
people that have a lot of information.
I think that companies really should spend more time looking at their employees as far
as what they post.
Putting out the VPN information is not a good idea.
Putting out what kind of cards they use, not a good idea.
So some governance around that would be a good idea.
Now we want to basically, basically now we've done our research and now we want to prepare
our pretext.
We really want to build those stories and have them very comfortable.
And so some of those that we can use, our new employee or contractor, that's good because
you can act confused.
Oh, I don't know where I'm going.
I'm not sure where the office is.
Can you help me?
Those are always really good.
Parking company attendant, make sure it's the right company, otherwise that can be a
red flag.
A lot of people like internet technician.
It's not one of my personal favorites, but I see it used all the time.
HVAC, that's one of my go-tos.
Personal trainer.
That's tricky, but doable.
And then security guard is tricky as well.
And make sure that you're not impersonating an official police or fire or anything like
that.
That has been done.
People have done that and they've gone to jail.
So you want to stay clear of that sort of thing.
Even if you are a criminal, I don't think it would be a good idea because the cost is
so high, right?
I think if you're doing this as an exercise, I still would not do that.
So I'm getting some connection errors as I'm moving forward.
So if I'm lagging out, please just tell me in the comments.
I think it's still good, but if it is lagging, let me know and I'll slow it down a little
bit.
All right.
So with our pretext, what we really want to do at the end of the day is make sure that
we're comfortable with our pretext and make sure that we have that feeling that we belong.
We should be able to walk into the building very comfortable.
That's what a good social engineer will achieve.
That level of comfort.
And not only that, but the level of almost invisibility.
So I should be able to walk in there and you're not going to look at me like, hmm, who's that
and what are they doing?
So almost that gray man sort of feel, right?
So I can kind of walk past people without drawing a lot of attention.
I mean, you could go the other way and get a lot of attention just to look more like
you belong, but I wouldn't recommend that.
It's too high risk.
So pretext, if you get caught, a lot of people in the social engineering world will say,
if you get caught, just keep with the same pretext.
Even when they're putting the handcuffs on, just stay with the same pretext.
I don't really believe that.
I think that you can evolve.
One of my favorites that I've always wanted to do is congratulate people and say, hey,
congratulations, you caught me because that makes people feel good, right?
And that's the whole objective of social engineering is to make people feel good and happy.
So I love that dialogue, right?
So hey, congratulations, you caught me.
I'm here to test your defenses.
Can you help me get to the next level and tell me how to open that door or something
like that, right?
Like bring them into it if you want.
And I think that would work on other CTFs like the SCCTF as well.
So if you ever have done that, let me know because it's one of my favorites.
I always like to evolve that.
Property management.
That's quite often a good one unless you run into property management.
Locksmith.
That's really, I think, quite a good one because the risk there is much lower.
Locked out of my office, that's higher risk because they may say, well, no, that's not
your office.
I've had that happen on phone calls before.
And then just a random employee just fumbling around could work too.
So those are some, but of course, your knowledge is going to vary.
So pick ones that work for you.
Now we're on site.
We've done all of our research on site.
We're showing up to the building and we want to kind of case the building out.
See if our research is still accurate, right?
So that classic saying, trust, but verify, right?
So we want to trust our research, but verify that it's still correct because they may have
made changes.
There may be construction, there may be new CCTV cameras, and we want to be very careful
that we don't expose ourselves to those cameras before we even start.
And I think that as far as defenses on your building, real criminals, when they're doing
their reconnaissance, as little as they may do, they're going to be conscious of that.
So when they see the camera, fake or real, they're going to have a reaction to that.
So I think that's as far as layering your defenses go, cameras are an excellent option.
Of course, you want to make sure you're covering certain areas with it, of course.
So what I'm going to look for when I arrive on site, of course, what's changed?
What's the same?
Are there guards, door locks?
If I can take a look at the door locks and get close enough for that without a camera
capturing me, or if I can hide myself, my face when I'm looking at that, that's really
what I want to try to do is get in there, take a look, a close look at those locks.
That's going to tell me what level I'm going to do.
Am I going to do just lock picking, or am I going to just bust the door and the lock?
Any sort of man traps.
I want to try to avoid all of those if I can.
I'll take a look at the back door.
Is that an easier option?
Any new opportunities as well.
So we talked about new risk, but there could be new opportunities.
So construction could be a great new opportunity.
Usually there's a lot of chaos there.
So things like that, I definitely want to take a look at.
Now the front door, this is the most obvious choice for an attack.
However, it is also the most complex.
And so because our operation is going to be quite lengthy, we're going quite deep into
the building and we're going really into one of the most risky areas.
We probably want to be as stealthy as possible when we go in.
And real attackers will often do this as well, unless there's very few people in the building
and the risk of noise and destruction is low.
But initially, especially as I'm going through the first layers of a defense, I kind of want
to test it out.
So if I do get caught, I haven't broken anything.
I'm not liable.
So I can just say, oh, sorry, wrong building.
I was looking for my doctor's office, right?
So I usually want to be more stealthy, at least initially.
Front doors usually are very difficult.
Highest level of surveillance, man traps, active guards, receptionists, forced interaction
quite often, which is difficult.
So they could ask you, oh, excuse me, can I help you?
And really good companies with a good security culture will do that.
They'll train their receptionists to do that sort of thing, to make interaction, to make
eye contact.
If the people come in the building, don't make eye contact, that can be a red flag.
And especially if you don't recognize them.
Of course, if you recognize them as a standard employee, that's different.
But yeah, so front door is often difficult.
One of the things that I think would be, this is more of a sophisticated attack for attackers,
but I think it has so much potential.
With the cloning of cards, if I can clone a card, I can basically walk in like I own
the place.
Because now I do.
I can put in this device, this ESP key, I walk up to the card scanner, especially if
it's on the outside, and put on my shirt that says I'm the card manufacturer, I'm swapping
out the batteries, have somebody with a clipboard standing over me, making sure I'm doing everything
correctly.
Five minute job, plug this in, now it's sending your creds to my phone in the parking lot,
I collect everything, and now I can walk in as anybody with that card.
So much more sophisticated than your average attacker would do.
But if security is high on your list, especially physical security, I would make sure you've
got the tamper alarms on these devices, so that if people try to go do this, they're
not taking everything from you.
So I found from my research, not many of these do.
So that's not good.
All right, front door, don't have the access card, you're gonna walk in with social engineering,
passive entry method.
This dude is awesome, right?
He's got a big smile, so friendly.
You're gonna say good morning to this guy as he walks through, hey, can I help you with
the door?
He's all loaded up with stuff, right?
That's great.
So he's got his tool belt, right, which makes him look legitimate, but also it's a great
place to put your forced entry tools.
So you've got everything, so it doesn't look like you're carrying this big bag of criminal
intent, right?
It's really, I'm just a legit guy trying to do some work.
So good in so many ways.
And so yeah, being able to carry your tools in there, so now you're ready, you're all
set up for that forced entry, should you need to use it.
Now covert entry mode on front doors, this door, you can see it kind of on the bottom
half of this image, this type of door lock is very popular in warmer climates.
You see it all over the place.
But of course there's a tool for that, which can quickly allow you to open that.
You can fix the door so that it won't do that, which I would highly recommend because this
door to open it is about 30 seconds, if that, if you know what you're doing.
And this tool is super easy to use.
A lot of people, that's their front door.
And once you're past that, you usually have entry to a lot of other stuff.
So I highly recommend if you're in the physical security area or responsibility for your company,
take a look at those super easy, minimal time.
All right, forced entry mode for the front door.
And these are the first responder boxes that you will sometimes see.
They're usually put in a place where you wouldn't necessarily look, but this basically, just
like cloning a card will give you God mode to your building.
Inside these boxes are every lock for your building because they're designed for firemen
to open.
And if there's a fire to use to go through your building.
So if you are responsible for the security, physical security in your building, you may
want to talk to the property management about these boxes and see what they do actually
contain.
Because if I break this open, which is totally possible, if I can find it, most people don't
know what these are.
So the risk for real criminals is fairly low, but once you get it, you have God mode.
So find out what's in the box, what they have access to.
Maybe they don't need access to your data center, right?
Maybe they don't need access to the executive floor.
So there's some things there.
Once I get this, sure, there might be an alarm on your building, but if every employee has
the code, I'm going to guess one of those common codes are going to work.
And I'm all set, right?
So something to look into.
Now you'll see that these come in several different forms depending on what country
you're in.
I've got some other examples there.
And there's a great presentation specifically on this from the RSA Conference 2013, where
he goes through these a little bit more.
But these are a real risk.
Luckily, not many people know about them, but they're becoming more popular since 2013.
So definitely take a look at that.
Now we're going to get into some of the forced entry tools that would be used.
And some of these are used by criminals.
They will be modified and simplified by criminals.
And of course, the time taken to use these as well is going to be longer.
So and I'm going to show you how long it takes to use some of these tools.
The classic wedge, this is usually made out of aluminum.
It's lightweight.
It's got the holes to reduce the weight.
But it's a critical tool.
And it's quite often, sometimes criminals will use a rock or whatever they can find
from opportunity to do this.
But it's basically used to jam into a door or window or any entry point to make space.
So you can then leverage more.
So if you see one of these things lying outside of your building or something similar, you
probably want to remove it.
So one of the things you can do for physical security is not only do surveillance around
your building, but just do a walk around once in a while and see what kind of debris is
out there.
So you don't want things like this lying around outside because criminals will just pick them
up and use them.
Part of the fireman's kit and first responders kit, and they're a great tool.
Wire cutters.
So wire cutters or side cutters sometimes used are called.
Great for cutting wire.
So if you have a fence, we could cut that.
But also for shearing the nails or screws that are sometimes used in a door.
So they're multipurpose, highly effective, a lot of leverage with those.
I can also use them as a poor man's wedge as well.
So if you see these lying around, that's a bad sign.
This is a little bit more interesting, right?
If you see this in someone's tool belt, that's going to be more of a tell than just wire
cutters.
Wire cutters look fairly benign, but these are modified channel lock pliers.
And the beautiful thing about these is you now have a multi-tool, three different tools
in one.
The classic usage of this tool is to simply remove your lock.
That Mortise lock that I have a picture of on the left there.
I can just unscrew that with this tool, pop it out, your door opens.
Very quick to do.
And a lot of front doors will have that.
And so you may want to take a look at that.
Make sure it's not your only line of defense, right?
This tool you're probably fairly familiar with, the shove knife.
This is very common.
If you go to conferences, you can quite often buy this.
I'm not going to go too deep into it because I think the lock picking community has a fairly
good familiarity with it.
But it is a great tool to have because it will solve a lot of your problems with locked
doors, unfortunately.
You can use it many different ways depending on the type of door handle that you're dealing
with.
But a great tool to have if you want to play with lock picking, this tool is a great thing
to practice because it is such a common problem solver with doors.
Now we're getting into more of the harder core first responder forced entry tools.
This is called a roof hook.
It's quite a long tool.
It gives you a lot of leverage.
It gives you multiple tools in one, chiseling, smashing.
It's like a lever action.
It's a very sophisticated tool, so I don't expect real attackers to use this very much.
There's other tools that are better.
The standard crowbar is probably used more by just common attackers.
But this one's a little bit more sophisticated.
This tool here is my personal favorite.
It's a shorter tool than the previous one.
It's crowbar or often called the halogen.
It's very common among firefighters because it is highly effective.
In the hands of the right person, this tool can basically help you move through almost
any door, usually in seconds, sometimes minutes, right?
So it gives you incredible leverage.
The different points on this tool can allow you to pop hinges, to remove rivets, to do
all sorts of amazing things very quickly.
So now we're going to take a look at the back door.
Those are some quick tools, but I'm going to talk about how to use them as well as we
proceed through.
But now let's take a look at that back door real quick.
So the back doors are quite often great for attackers.
Usually if you've got a loading dock, that's usually wide open, there's usually people
out there relaxing, not really relaxing, but taking breaks sometimes and just moving things
around.
A little bit of chaos is great for an attacker to kind of move through.
One of the things to watch out for as an attacker is if there's people that are diligent
on safety.
Usually it's less security and more safety, right?
Hey, are you wearing a hard hat?
Hey, are those steel toed boots?
Especially in a union environment or something like that, you could definitely see some of
that going on.
So if an attacker is going to move through here, it can be difficult if they're not dressed
in the right attire with that sort of thing.
But it also makes a great egress option, right?
So if attackers are coming out, that could be a place they would want to exit from because
moving past that, it's going to be actually easier than going in for sure.
Back doors.
So quite often back doors are overlooked a little bit, right?
They're usually an exit point, not always an entry point.
So it could be a place for forced entry or a better option for covert entry, of course,
lockpicking.
It usually avoids man traps as well.
So back doors and reception are usually not stationed there.
And then also it offers a good egress point as well, right?
So if I want to get out, that's a good idea.
If I'm coming in through that, through social engineering, I could do that if people are
having a smoke break, but it doesn't really legitimize my pretext as much as coming through
the front door would.
So if you have success coming in that way, you could leave that way.
So steel doors.
Quite often attackers will see steel doors there or you may use steel doors in your business.
On this particular case, I know that picture is a bit hard to see.
It's quite small, but it looks fairly secure, right?
It looks not too bad.
That can be breached in about two minutes.
So two minutes is not a long time, right?
Two minutes of, it's going to involve a little bit of noise, but two minutes is pretty quick,
right?
For a kind of run of the mill criminal, I think it's going to take more than two minutes,
of course, but still not that long if they have a crowbar and they kind of know what
they're doing.
A two-man team, definitely within two minutes with professionals.
There's no dead bolts.
There's no sophistication there other than just the steel door.
A lot of people will say, hey, Rob, attack the hinges.
Yeah, you can.
Some people will, and this tool is great for that.
It's a spring-loaded tool, so you can pull it and release it.
The idea is it pops the hinges, the hinge pins out.
Yeah, that could work, but what you'll find is now you're attacking three different areas
rather than just the one.
So hinges are doable and you definitely want to secure your hinges.
One of the things I'd recommend are stud hinges, especially on your outside perimeter.
That's a quick and easy option that you can do that will prevent a tool like this from
breaking your hinges.
Definitely take a look at that.
All this information is in my references slide at the very end of this.
So if you get my slide deck, you can find out where to buy this tool or the stud hinges
and things like that.
But I find going after the lock is quite often a better option.
And also if you break the hinges, it's non-reversible.
So when someone sees the door on the ground, that's going to be a pretty clear tell that
somebody's broken into the building.
So for more covert entry, not necessarily recommended.
More back doors.
So look at this door, right?
You've got the lock, the key lock.
You've also got a padlock and then you've got those studs in the door and those studs
represent an arm that is behind the door.
Quite often it's a wood two by four or something like that.
And this offers a little bit more challenge, right?
Because now you may be thinking, well, Rob, now I'm going to go for the hinges because
now that it's so secure, not necessarily the case, right?
So for example, that padlock, about five seconds, and I'm gonna show you how to do that.
The studs, again, just, you can either shear those off with your side cutters or pop them
out with your halogen, just bash them through.
And then that lock can be removed with your vice grips, right?
So not that difficult still.
I mean, much more of a deterrent for your street criminals, for sure.
And I think this would be a recommended perimeter back door for sure, because criminals are
going to look at that and go, yeah, maybe not.
But not totally safe.
This shows you the aftermath of that, right?
So cutting the deadbolt or popping it, the work arm, you can discard that once you pop
those, and it doesn't actually show that, but those studs or rivets there, you just
pop those through or grind them off.
So that's about six minutes with a two-man team.
So a little longer, you definitely made some time there.
And adding more time is good because the noise is going to be heard hopefully by other people.
Now, for anybody who's watched No Country for Old Men, this is kind of the over-the-counter
equivalent of that tool.
If you haven't watched that show and you're interested in physical security, the show
is a bit gory, okay?
There's some violence in the show, so extreme violence.
So if you're not into that, don't watch it.
But the tool that he is carrying is a multipurpose tool, unfortunately, but one of the purposes
that it's used for is removing locks off of doors.
It does it very quickly.
The tool on the left, you can buy for $230 American, I think it is, might be Canadian.
And it's very quick, and it's not very loud.
If you're familiar with Lockpick Lawyer, you can go to his website or his YouTube channel.
It's amazing.
Anything to do with breaking locks or lockpicking, fantastic resources, it's in my resources
page.
But this, you could put it in your belt loop, walk up to a padlock, boom, it's open.
And it will be a little bit loud because it takes a 22 shell or a 0.27 round shell
to open it, but it will open any lock, basically, right?
So pretty amazing, and you can just buy it over the counter.
Now you're in the lobby, you've gotten past the first perimeter, you're in the lobby,
and you're looking at what it's going to offer you.
So we want to watch out for these things, any sort of physical barriers, alarms, security
